collection.collection_description:
Preservation of audiotaped programming from faith groups. Originated with Methodist / United Methodist materials and expanded to include other religious groups. Programs include talk programs, radio interviews, news stories, lectures, class presentations, sermons, and more. Collection created by Mike Hickcox, originally with United Methodist Communications, then individually, in collaboration with the United Methodist General Commission on Archives and History. The purpose is to preserve significant audio presentations and to make them available to the public to search and to listen.

This collection has been identified as a 'target' collection for the Sound Submissions Project and is in the queue for acquisition and processing.
collection.historical_relevance: Contains hundreds of audio programs from the history of the Methodist / United Methodist Church as well as audio from other denominations. Contains extensive faith-based radio broadcasts from 1965-69 focusing on American social issues, with significant coverage of Civil Rights and the Vietnam War. The intersection of faith and American life is well represented in the collection and many of the most-involved figures of the time are represented.
physical_formats: Digital audio files (MP3, WAV, AIFF, etc.)
collection.access_statement: Audio can be heard by anyone at https://SoundTheology.org. The actual audiotapes are held around the country at the originating institutions.
collection.supporting_documentation: Documentation is in the database. Only some of that data is visible online.
